title: Genre: Narrative
objective: Apply narrative-reading strategies to historical stories

required_passages.text: A younger son demanded his inheritance, squandered it, and came to ruin. He returned in repentance, and his father ran to receive him with compassion and celebration. The older brother resented the mercy shown. The father replied that rejoicing is fitting because this brother was dead and is alive again, was lost and is found.

segments.audio_script: This is lesson seven. Begin genre analysis with narrative reading strategies.

Listen to the passage. Luke 15:11-32. A younger son demanded his inheritance, squandered it, and came to ruin. He returned in repentance, and his father ran to receive him with compassion and celebration. The older brother resented the mercy shown. The father replied that rejoicing is fitting because this brother was dead and is alive again, was lost and is found. Now identify plot movement, character contrast, and how the ending resolves the narrative tension.
Narrative teaches through events and character actions. Pay attention to authorial selection and sequence.
Ask about narrative point of view, focalization, and thematic refrains. Note what is included and omitted.
Key theme: narratives shape theology through story not propositional statement.
Name a structural feature to observe in narrative texts.
This completes lesson seven. Next lesson examines poetic texts and parallelism.
